concerns mount over london move -pipe- business -pipe- deutsche welle -pipe- 07.01.2005 main content main navigation extra content head navigation search choose form 30 languages about us press business & sales dw-akademie dw-store contact help partner site map archive search keywords search extended search your link to germany choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages english german chinese spanish portuguese for brazil arabic russian persian albanian amharic bengali bosnian b / h / s bulgarian croatian dari french greek hausa hindi indonesian kiswahili macedonian pashto polish portuguese romanian serbian turkish ukrainian urdu choose from 30 languages 28.12.2010 home news germany europe world asia business science & technology environment & development culture & lifestyle sports germany info visit germany facts about germany study in germany german courses learning german deutsch unterrichten german xxl dw-radio what 's on ?
programs reception audio on demand learning by ear dw-tv what 's on ?
program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de business -pipe- 07.01.2005 concerns mount over london move großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : deutsche börse 's bullish about winning over the lse there were growing speculation in germany friday that stock market operator deutsche börse might transfer its headquarters to london in its charm offensive to woo the london stock exchange -lrb- lse -rrb- . the german government , politicians and labour representatives all expressed concern friday that german national prestige damaged and jobs lost if a merged company were to be move its headquarters from the main river in frankfurt to the thames in london . " i can only call on deutsche börse to retain its headquarters in frankfurt , " if a merger with lse were to come about , green party politician christine scheel , head of the german parliament 's financial committee , told business daily handelsblatt .
the finance expert of the opposition conservative christian democratic union -lrb- cdu -rrb- and christian social union -lrb- csu -rrb- , heinz seiffert , also said that politicians should do everything to ensure that the decision regarding the merged company 's future headquarters should fall in germany 's favour . charm offensive bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : deutsche börse in frankfurt in the battle for the lse , deutsche börse appears to be pulling out all the stops to convince the lse of the virtues of a frankfurt-london tie-up rather than a merger with frankfurt 's arch-rival , paris-based rival euronext .
the german company has so far put a bid of just under € 2 billion -lrb- $ 2.6 billion -rrb- on the table for the london market .
but , in an effort to win over the lse , deutsche börse has not only changed its official language to english , but has reportedly offered to manage the combined cash equities markets out of london and has also offered lse chief clara furse that job . furthermore , newspaper reports this week said the operator of the frankfurt stock exchange was ready to raise its offer and might even consider selling its luxembourg-based learstream unit , which many observers saw as the main stumbling block to a london-frankfurt tie-up . constructive meeting bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : werner g. seifert furse met with deutsche börse chief werner seifert -lrb- pictured -rrb- in london on thursday . a spokesman for the german group said the talks had been " friendly , constructive and professional " .
he declined to provide any further details .
furse was said to be meeting euronext boss jean-francois theodore on friday .
those talks were confidential and their outcome would not be made public , well-informed sources in paris told afp .
the negotiations were likely to last weeks rather than days . a german finance ministry spokesman insisted that the government expected the decision about the location of the headquarters of any merged group to fall in frankfurt 's favor .
the merger talks were an expression " of the strength of germany as a financial centre " , the spokesman said .
and that strength would be further enhanced in the event of a merger . fear of loss of jobs but , deutsche börse 's employees appear to be alarmed that they could lose their jobs .
the financial times deutschland reported in its friday edition that the group 's works council saw " urgent need for consultation " between employee representatives and management on the matter .
chairman seifert had insisted that there would be no compulsory redundancies if a merger went ahead .
and financial sources said friday that such fears were " unfounded " .
indeed , jobs could be in greater peril if a merger did not take place and frankfurt saw its importance as a stock market dwindle , the sources said .
deutsche börse refused to comment on the report . dw staff / afp -lrb- sp -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de deutsche börse offers eurex to london german stock market operator deutsche boerse is offering to manage its derivatives business eurex from london as a sweetener to convince the london stock exchange of the advantages of a merger , the financial times reported on thursday .
-lrb- jan .
6 , 2005 -rrb- deutsche börse launches charm offensive in its bid to win over the london stock exchange -lrb- lse -rrb- , german stock market operator deutsche börse appeared to be pulling out all the stops on wednesday to convince its london rival of the virtues of a merger .

many see the fusion as a great opportunity in the markets , but not everyone is enthusiastic . -lrb- dec .

germans offer early warning help -pipe- germany -pipe- deutsche welle -pipe- 07.01.2005 main content main navigation extra content head navigation search choose form 30 languages about us press business & sales dw-akademie contact help partner site map archive search keywords search extended search your link to germany choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages english german chinese spanish portuguese for brazil arabic russian persian albanian amharic bengali bosnian b / h / s bulgarian croatian dari french greek hausa hindi indonesian kiswahili macedonian pashto polish portuguese for africa romanian serbian turkish ukrainian urdu choose from 30 languages 02.07.2011 home news germany europe world asia business science & technology environment & development culture & lifestyle sports germany info visit germany facts about germany study in germany german courses learning german deutsch unterrichten german xxl dw-radio about dw-radio what 's on ?
reception audio on demand learning by ear dw-tv what 's on ?
program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de in focus : the asian tsunami : one year after doing better than " business as usual " german organizations take stock of tsunami relief an endeavor that needs time and money german tsunami early warning system takes shape germany -pipe- 07.01.2005 germans offer early warning help großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : an early warning system could prevent future devastation there 's long been talk of creating a tsunami warning system , but now it 's time for action .
dw-world spoke to birger-gottfried lühr of the geo research center in potsdam , which wants to help . dw-world : at the donor conference for the tsunami victims , it was decided to introduce a warning system to the affected region .
what would be the exact role of the geo research center in implementing such a system ?
birger-gottfried lühr : our area of expertise is recording seismic activity and quickly analyzing signals registered .
in addition to this , each year we conduct a seismology training course , held alternately in potsdam and a country which is endangered by seismic activity .
so that means it would largely be your task to quickly recognize earthquakes .
but not every earthquake leads to a tsunami .
no , only a small number of earthquakes trigger tsunamis , but besides volcanic eruptions , they are the main cause .
it is critical to be able to recognize that an earthquake is coming and be able to see their movement in order to determine the likelihood of a tsunami .
what else would be involved in an early warning system besides an ability to recognize the danger in time ?
early warning does n't mean erecting a box somewhere which would ring at the critical moment .
we need a system which transports information from the decision-makers to the fishermen on the beach , who would then need to know what to do .
so it 's also a problem of training and understanding .
how long would it take to get such a system up and running ?
even if we were to set to it with the same verve as the japanese or the americans , it would still take a couple of years .
they are still improving their own system .
at the donor conference , kofi annan noted that japan could play a leading role in an early warning system , given that the japanese system is already very good .
does that mean it would be japanese rather than german researchers providing the technology for an early warning system ?
i think this incident has proven that natural catastrophes are a global problem .
every country on the planet should work together to reduce risk .
it is definitely an advantage that japan has already done some of the footwork , but i do n't believe the japanese should do it on their own .
have there already been international efforts to create a better system of protection against natural catastrophes ?
yes , we 've been thinking about this task for a long time .
there was a united nations initiative for the reduction of natural catastrophes between 1990 and 2000 , and there is also an initiative for the future , which would build on this .
so , yes , in the wider context , some preliminary work has already been done .
is there any existing cooperation between the different research institutes ?
yes , we are not starting from scratch .
we already work with many groups on a scientific level , we already have contacts with scientists .
i am part of a project which works in java and the sunda islands , and there are a number of indonesian institutes involved .
we run a network with many stations across the world which record earthquakes , but they have to be improved , concentrated and appraised .
has the geo research institute received any official requests to become involved ?
as an employee here , i have noticed certain signals that there is a wish for us to become more actively involved . markus roman -lrb- tkw -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de germany keen on south asia partnerships chancellor schröder wants to go beyond immediate financial and humanitarian aid to the tsunami-hit nations by proposing bilateral " partnerships . "
the idea of long-term help has found takers in germany .
-lrb- jan .
04 , 2005 -rrb- german scientist : tsunami warning possible eyewitnesses of the tsunamis that hit south asia following sunday 's underwater earthquake said the wall of water hit without warning , but a german seismologist said that , in principle , a warning was possible .
-lrb- dec .
27 , 2005 -rrb- leaders agree to tsunami warning system world leaders at an aid summit in the indonesian capital jakarta on thursday agreed to set up a tsunami early warning system .
debt repayment for affected countries will also be delayed .
-lrb- dec .
06 , 2005 -rrb- www-links geo research center potsdam official web site radio news listen to world headlines from the top of the hour .

art german photographer lala aufsberg 's work is a fascinating historical record of the 20th century .

program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de in focus : the asian tsunami : one year after doing better than " business as usual " german organizations take stock of tsunami relief an endeavor that needs time and money german tsunami early warning system takes shape germany -pipe- 07.01.2005 germans offer early warning help großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : an early warning system could prevent future devastation there 's long been talk of creating a tsunami warning system , but now it 's time for action .
dw-world spoke to birger-gottfried lühr of the geo research center in potsdam , which wants to help . dw-world : at the donor conference for the tsunami victims , it was decided to introduce a warning system to the affected region .
what would be the exact role of the geo research center in implementing such a system ?
birger-gottfried lühr : our area of expertise is recording seismic activity and quickly analyzing signals registered .
in addition to this , each year we conduct a seismology training course , held alternately in potsdam and a country which is endangered by seismic activity .
so that means it would largely be your task to quickly recognize earthquakes .
but not every earthquake leads to a tsunami .
no , only a small number of earthquakes trigger tsunamis , but besides volcanic eruptions , they are the main cause .
it is critical to be able to recognize that an earthquake is coming and be able to see their movement in order to determine the likelihood of a tsunami .
what else would be involved in an early warning system besides an ability to recognize the danger in time ?
early warning does n't mean erecting a box somewhere which would ring at the critical moment .
we need a system which transports information from the decision-makers to the fishermen on the beach , who would then need to know what to do .
so it 's also a problem of training and understanding .
how long would it take to get such a system up and running ?
even if we were to set to it with the same verve as the japanese or the americans , it would still take a couple of years .
they are still improving their own system .
at the donor conference , kofi annan noted that japan could play a leading role in an early warning system , given that the japanese system is already very good .
does that mean it would be japanese rather than german researchers providing the technology for an early warning system ?
i think this incident has proven that natural catastrophes are a global problem .
every country on the planet should work together to reduce risk .
it is definitely an advantage that japan has already done some of the footwork , but i do n't believe the japanese should do it on their own .
have there already been international efforts to create a better system of protection against natural catastrophes ?
yes , we 've been thinking about this task for a long time .
there was a united nations initiative for the reduction of natural catastrophes between 1990 and 2000 , and there is also an initiative for the future , which would build on this .
so , yes , in the wider context , some preliminary work has already been done .
is there any existing cooperation between the different research institutes ?
yes , we are not starting from scratch .
we already work with many groups on a scientific level , we already have contacts with scientists .
i am part of a project which works in java and the sunda islands , and there are a number of indonesian institutes involved .
we run a network with many stations across the world which record earthquakes , but they have to be improved , concentrated and appraised .
has the geo research institute received any official requests to become involved ?
as an employee here , i have noticed certain signals that there is a wish for us to become more actively involved . markus roman -lrb- tkw -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de germany keen on south asia partnerships chancellor schröder wants to go beyond immediate financial and humanitarian aid to the tsunami-hit nations by proposing bilateral " partnerships . "
the idea of long-term help has found takers in germany .
-lrb- jan .
04 , 2005 -rrb- german scientist : tsunami warning possible eyewitnesses of the tsunamis that hit south asia following sunday 's underwater earthquake said the wall of water hit without warning , but a german seismologist said that , in principle , a warning was possible .
-lrb- dec .
27 , 2005 -rrb- leaders agree to tsunami warning system world leaders at an aid summit in the indonesian capital jakarta on thursday agreed to set up a tsunami early warning system .
debt repayment for affected countries will also be delayed .
-lrb- dec .
06 , 2005 -rrb- www-links geo research center potsdam official web site feedback email us your thoughts on the implementation of an early warning system .
please include your name and country in your reply . radio news listen to world headlines from the top of the hour .
dw-tv europe live journal we 're sorry , due to legal issues this content can not be transmitted as live stream .
if you are inside the united states , it is still possible for you to enjoy dw-tv .
for more information , please click here .
dw-radio live in-box feedback from around the world listen live travel discover germany munich offers everything from culture and fashion to relaxation and recreation .
feature life behind the wall dw-tv presents a unique animated depiction of the former german-german border .
dw-radio living in germany learn more about german society by listening to this weekly radio program .

so that means it would largely be your task to quickly recognize earthquakes .
but not every earthquake leads to a tsunami .
no , only a small number of earthquakes trigger tsunamis , but besides volcanic eruptions , they are the main cause .

so , yes , in the wider context , some preliminary work has already been done .
is there any existing cooperation between the different research institutes ?
yes , we are not starting from scratch .
we already work with many groups on a scientific level , we already have contacts with scientists .
i am part of a project which works in java and the sunda islands , and there are a number of indonesian institutes involved .
we run a network with many stations across the world which record earthquakes , but they have to be improved , concentrated and appraised .
has the geo research institute received any official requests to become involved ?
as an employee here , i have noticed certain signals that there is a wish for us to become more actively involved . markus roman -lrb- tkw -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de germany keen on south asia partnerships chancellor schröder wants to go beyond immediate financial and humanitarian aid to the tsunami-hit nations by proposing bilateral " partnerships . program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de in focus : the asian tsunami : one year after doing better than " business as usual " german organizations take stock of tsunami relief an endeavor that needs time and money german tsunami early warning system takes shape germany -pipe- 07.01.2005 germans offer early warning help großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : an early warning system could prevent future devastation there 's long been talk of creating a tsunami warning system , but now it 's time for action .
dw-world spoke to birger-gottfried lühr of the geo research center in potsdam , which wants to help . dw-world : at the donor conference for the tsunami victims , it was decided to introduce a warning system to the affected region .
what would be the exact role of the geo research center in implementing such a system ?
birger-gottfried lühr : our area of expertise is recording seismic activity and quickly analyzing signals registered .
in addition to this , each year we conduct a seismology training course , held alternately in potsdam and a country which is endangered by seismic activity .
so that means it would largely be your task to quickly recognize earthquakes .
but not every earthquake leads to a tsunami .
no , only a small number of earthquakes trigger tsunamis , but besides volcanic eruptions , they are the main cause .
it is critical to be able to recognize that an earthquake is coming and be able to see their movement in order to determine the likelihood of a tsunami .
what else would be involved in an early warning system besides an ability to recognize the danger in time ?
early warning does n't mean erecting a box somewhere which would ring at the critical moment .
we need a system which transports information from the decision-makers to the fishermen on the beach , who would then need to know what to do .
so it 's also a problem of training and understanding .
how long would it take to get such a system up and running ?
even if we were to set to it with the same verve as the japanese or the americans , it would still take a couple of years .
they are still improving their own system .
at the donor conference , kofi annan noted that japan could play a leading role in an early warning system , given that the japanese system is already very good .
does that mean it would be japanese rather than german researchers providing the technology for an early warning system ?
i think this incident has proven that natural catastrophes are a global problem .
every country on the planet should work together to reduce risk .
it is definitely an advantage that japan has already done some of the footwork , but i do n't believe the japanese should do it on their own .
have there already been international efforts to create a better system of protection against natural catastrophes ?
yes , we 've been thinking about this task for a long time .
there was a united nations initiative for the reduction of natural catastrophes between 1990 and 2000 , and there is also an initiative for the future , which would build on this .
so , yes , in the wider context , some preliminary work has already been done .
is there any existing cooperation between the different research institutes ?
yes , we are not starting from scratch .
we already work with many groups on a scientific level , we already have contacts with scientists .
i am part of a project which works in java and the sunda islands , and there are a number of indonesian institutes involved .
we run a network with many stations across the world which record earthquakes , but they have to be improved , concentrated and appraised .
has the geo research institute received any official requests to become involved ?
as an employee here , i have noticed certain signals that there is a wish for us to become more actively involved . markus roman -lrb- tkw -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de germany keen on south asia partnerships chancellor schröder wants to go beyond immediate financial and humanitarian aid to the tsunami-hit nations by proposing bilateral " partnerships . "

program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de in focus : the asian tsunami : one year after doing better than " business as usual " german organizations take stock of tsunami relief an endeavor that needs time and money german tsunami early warning system takes shape germany -pipe- 07.01.2005 germans offer early warning help großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : an early warning system could prevent future devastation there 's long been talk of creating a tsunami warning system , but now it 's time for action .
dw-world spoke to birger-gottfried lühr of the geo research center in potsdam , which wants to help . dw-world : at the donor conference for the tsunami victims , it was decided to introduce a warning system to the affected region .
what would be the exact role of the geo research center in implementing such a system ?
birger-gottfried lühr : our area of expertise is recording seismic activity and quickly analyzing signals registered .
in addition to this , each year we conduct a seismology training course , held alternately in potsdam and a country which is endangered by seismic activity .
so that means it would largely be your task to quickly recognize earthquakes .
but not every earthquake leads to a tsunami .
no , only a small number of earthquakes trigger tsunamis , but besides volcanic eruptions , they are the main cause .
it is critical to be able to recognize that an earthquake is coming and be able to see their movement in order to determine the likelihood of a tsunami .
what else would be involved in an early warning system besides an ability to recognize the danger in time ?
early warning does n't mean erecting a box somewhere which would ring at the critical moment .
we need a system which transports information from the decision-makers to the fishermen on the beach , who would then need to know what to do .
so it 's also a problem of training and understanding .
how long would it take to get such a system up and running ?
even if we were to set to it with the same verve as the japanese or the americans , it would still take a couple of years .
they are still improving their own system .
at the donor conference , kofi annan noted that japan could play a leading role in an early warning system , given that the japanese system is already very good .
does that mean it would be japanese rather than german researchers providing the technology for an early warning system ?
i think this incident has proven that natural catastrophes are a global problem .
every country on the planet should work together to reduce risk .
it is definitely an advantage that japan has already done some of the footwork , but i do n't believe the japanese should do it on their own .
have there already been international efforts to create a better system of protection against natural catastrophes ?
yes , we 've been thinking about this task for a long time .
there was a united nations initiative for the reduction of natural catastrophes between 1990 and 2000 , and there is also an initiative for the future , which would build on this .
so , yes , in the wider context , some preliminary work has already been done .
is there any existing cooperation between the different research institutes ?
yes , we are not starting from scratch .
we already work with many groups on a scientific level , we already have contacts with scientists .
i am part of a project which works in java and the sunda islands , and there are a number of indonesian institutes involved .
we run a network with many stations across the world which record earthquakes , but they have to be improved , concentrated and appraised .
has the geo research institute received any official requests to become involved ?
as an employee here , i have noticed certain signals that there is a wish for us to become more actively involved . markus roman -lrb- tkw -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de germany keen on south asia partnerships chancellor schröder wants to go beyond immediate financial and humanitarian aid to the tsunami-hit nations by proposing bilateral " partnerships . "
the idea of long-term help has found takers in germany .
-lrb- jan .
04 , 2005 -rrb- german scientist : tsunami warning possible eyewitnesses of the tsunamis that hit south asia following sunday 's underwater earthquake said the wall of water hit without warning , but a german seismologist said that , in principle , a warning was possible .
-lrb- dec .
27 , 2005 -rrb- leaders agree to tsunami warning system world leaders at an aid summit in the indonesian capital jakarta on thursday agreed to set up a tsunami early warning system .
debt repayment for affected countries will also be delayed .
-lrb- dec .
06 , 2005 -rrb- www-links geo research center potsdam official web site feedback email us your thoughts on the implementation of an early warning system .

but not every earthquake leads to a tsunami .
no , only a small number of earthquakes trigger tsunamis , but besides volcanic eruptions , they are the main cause .
it is critical to be able to recognize that an earthquake is coming and be able to see their movement in order to determine the likelihood of a tsunami .

so it 's also a problem of training and understanding .
how long would it take to get such a system up and running ?
even if we were to set to it with the same verve as the japanese or the americans , it would still take a couple of years .
they are still improving their own system .
at the donor conference , kofi annan noted that japan could play a leading role in an early warning system , given that the japanese system is already very good .
does that mean it would be japanese rather than german researchers providing the technology for an early warning system ?
i think this incident has proven that natural catastrophes are a global problem .
every country on the planet should work together to reduce risk .
it is definitely an advantage that japan has already done some of the footwork , but i do n't believe the japanese should do it on their own .
have there already been international efforts to create a better system of protection against natural catastrophes ?
yes , we 've been thinking about this task for a long time .
there was a united nations initiative for the reduction of natural catastrophes between 1990 and 2000 , and there is also an initiative for the future , which would build on this .
so , yes , in the wider context , some preliminary work has already been done .
is there any existing cooperation between the different research institutes ?
yes , we are not starting from scratch .
we already work with many groups on a scientific level , we already have contacts with scientists .
i am part of a project which works in java and the sunda islands , and there are a number of indonesian institutes involved .
we run a network with many stations across the world which record earthquakes , but they have to be improved , concentrated and appraised .
has the geo research institute received any official requests to become involved ?
as an employee here , i have noticed certain signals that there is a wish for us to become more actively involved . markus roman -lrb- tkw -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de germany keen on south asia partnerships chancellor schröder wants to go beyond immediate financial and humanitarian aid to the tsunami-hit nations by proposing bilateral " partnerships . germans offer early warning help -pipe- germany -pipe- deutsche welle -pipe- 07.01.2005 main content main navigation extra content head navigation search choose form 30 languages about us press business & sales dw-akademie dw-store contact help partner site map archive search keywords search extended search your link to germany choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages english german chinese spanish portuguese for brazil arabic russian persian albanian amharic bengali bosnian b / h / s bulgarian croatian dari french greek hausa hindi indonesian kiswahili macedonian pashto polish portuguese romanian serbian turkish ukrainian urdu choose from 30 languages 28.12.2010 home news germany german reunification europe world asia business science & technology environment & development culture & lifestyle sports germany info visit germany facts about germany study in germany german courses learning german deutsch unterrichten german xxl dw-radio what 's on ?

program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de in focus : the asian tsunami : one year after doing better than " business as usual " german organizations take stock of tsunami relief an endeavor that needs time and money german tsunami early warning system takes shape germany -pipe- 07.01.2005 germans offer early warning help großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : an early warning system could prevent future devastation there 's long been talk of creating a tsunami warning system , but now it 's time for action .
dw-world spoke to birger-gottfried lühr of the geo research center in potsdam , which wants to help . dw-world : at the donor conference for the tsunami victims , it was decided to introduce a warning system to the affected region .
what would be the exact role of the geo research center in implementing such a system ?
birger-gottfried lühr : our area of expertise is recording seismic activity and quickly analyzing signals registered .
in addition to this , each year we conduct a seismology training course , held alternately in potsdam and a country which is endangered by seismic activity .
so that means it would largely be your task to quickly recognize earthquakes .
but not every earthquake leads to a tsunami .
no , only a small number of earthquakes trigger tsunamis , but besides volcanic eruptions , they are the main cause .
it is critical to be able to recognize that an earthquake is coming and be able to see their movement in order to determine the likelihood of a tsunami .
what else would be involved in an early warning system besides an ability to recognize the danger in time ?
early warning does n't mean erecting a box somewhere which would ring at the critical moment .
we need a system which transports information from the decision-makers to the fishermen on the beach , who would then need to know what to do .
so it 's also a problem of training and understanding .
how long would it take to get such a system up and running ?
even if we were to set to it with the same verve as the japanese or the americans , it would still take a couple of years .
they are still improving their own system .
at the donor conference , kofi annan noted that japan could play a leading role in an early warning system , given that the japanese system is already very good .
does that mean it would be japanese rather than german researchers providing the technology for an early warning system ?
i think this incident has proven that natural catastrophes are a global problem .
every country on the planet should work together to reduce risk .
it is definitely an advantage that japan has already done some of the footwork , but i do n't believe the japanese should do it on their own .
have there already been international efforts to create a better system of protection against natural catastrophes ?
yes , we 've been thinking about this task for a long time .
there was a united nations initiative for the reduction of natural catastrophes between 1990 and 2000 , and there is also an initiative for the future , which would build on this .
so , yes , in the wider context , some preliminary work has already been done .
is there any existing cooperation between the different research institutes ?
yes , we are not starting from scratch .
we already work with many groups on a scientific level , we already have contacts with scientists .
i am part of a project which works in java and the sunda islands , and there are a number of indonesian institutes involved .
we run a network with many stations across the world which record earthquakes , but they have to be improved , concentrated and appraised .
has the geo research institute received any official requests to become involved ?
as an employee here , i have noticed certain signals that there is a wish for us to become more actively involved . markus roman -lrb- tkw -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de germany keen on south asia partnerships chancellor schröder wants to go beyond immediate financial and humanitarian aid to the tsunami-hit nations by proposing bilateral " partnerships . "
the idea of long-term help has found takers in germany .
-lrb- jan .
04 , 2005 -rrb- german scientist : tsunami warning possible eyewitnesses of the tsunamis that hit south asia following sunday 's underwater earthquake said the wall of water hit without warning , but a german seismologist said that , in principle , a warning was possible .
-lrb- dec .
27 , 2005 -rrb- leaders agree to tsunami warning system world leaders at an aid summit in the indonesian capital jakarta on thursday agreed to set up a tsunami early warning system .
debt repayment for affected countries will also be delayed .
-lrb- dec .
06 , 2005 -rrb- www-links geo research center potsdam official web site feedback email us your thoughts on the implementation of an early warning system .
please include your name and country in your reply . radio news listen to world headlines from the top of the hour .

program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de business -pipe- 07.01.2005 -pipe- 13:00 utc bundesbank profits hit by strong euro the sharp rise in the euro at the end of last year has whittled down the bundesbank 's 2004 annual profit to almost zero , a central bank spokesman said on thursday .
earlier , regional daily passauer neue presse had quoted government sources as saying that the euro 's surge to record highs against the dollar at the end of last year meant the central bank would have to make heavy writedowns against its dollar reserves , effectively wiping out its 2004 annual profit .
that spells bad news for germany 's severely straitened public finances.german finance minister hans eichel had been pencilling in a bundesbank profit of around € 2 billion -lrb- $ 2.6 billion -rrb- for 2004 , which he could use for the 2005 budget .
the bundesbank is scheduled to publish its 2004 annual accounts in mid-march . dw-world.de opinion : has the euro changed anything ?
many germans still calculate prices in marks and those who have less money in their wallets than three years ago - when the new currency was introduced - wonder whether the euro is to blame .
-lrb- dec .
23 , 2004 -rrb- more briefs 06.01.2005 -pipe- tax amnesty raises money for germany 06.01.2005 -pipe- trucks avoid german highways 06.01.2005 -pipe- deutsche börse offers eurex to london 05.01.2005 -pipe- eu approves deficit breach for tsunami aid 05.01.2005 -pipe- anti-cancer drug to come out soon 05.01.2005 -pipe- nordlb seeks € 800 million injection 05.01.2005 -pipe- audi employees to work longer 04.01.2005 -pipe- euro-zone inflation edges up in december radio news listen to world headlines from the top of the hour .

program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de business -pipe- 07.01.2005 -pipe- 13:00 utc bundesbank profits hit by strong euro the sharp rise in the euro at the end of last year has whittled down the bundesbank 's 2004 annual profit to almost zero , a central bank spokesman said on thursday .
earlier , regional daily passauer neue presse had quoted government sources as saying that the euro 's surge to record highs against the dollar at the end of last year meant the central bank would have to make heavy writedowns against its dollar reserves , effectively wiping out its 2004 annual profit .
that spells bad news for germany 's severely straitened public finances.german finance minister hans eichel had been pencilling in a bundesbank profit of around € 2 billion -lrb- $ 2.6 billion -rrb- for 2004 , which he could use for the 2005 budget .
the bundesbank is scheduled to publish its 2004 annual accounts in mid-march . dw-world.de opinion : has the euro changed anything ?
many germans still calculate prices in marks and those who have less money in their wallets than three years ago - when the new currency was introduced - wonder whether the euro is to blame .
-lrb- dec .
23 , 2004 -rrb- more briefs 06.01.2005 -pipe- tax amnesty raises money for germany 06.01.2005 -pipe- trucks avoid german highways 06.01.2005 -pipe- deutsche börse offers eurex to london 05.01.2005 -pipe- eu approves deficit breach for tsunami aid 05.01.2005 -pipe- anti-cancer drug to come out soon 05.01.2005 -pipe- nordlb seeks € 800 million injection 05.01.2005 -pipe- audi employees to work longer 04.01.2005 -pipe- euro-zone inflation edges up in december radio news listen to world headlines from the top of the hour .
european business week listen to the latest edition of european business week media center watch and listen explore new content daily in dw 's multimedia archive .
dw-tv europe live journal - nachrichten mit wirtschaftsbilanz we 're sorry , due to legal issues this content can not be transmitted as live stream .
if you are inside the united states , it is still possible for you to enjoy dw-tv .
for more information , please click here .

bringing home the dead -pipe- current affairs -pipe- deutsche welle -pipe- 07.01.2005 main content main navigation extra content head navigation search choose form 30 languages about us press business & sales dw-akademie contact help partner site map archive search keywords search extended search your link to germany choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages english german chinese spanish portuguese for brazil arabic russian persian albanian amharic bengali bosnian b / h / s bulgarian croatian dari french greek hausa hindi indonesian kiswahili macedonian pashto polish portuguese for africa romanian serbian turkish ukrainian urdu choose from 30 languages 01.07.2011 home news germany europe world asia business science & technology environment & development culture & lifestyle sports germany info visit germany facts about germany study in germany german courses learning german deutsch unterrichten german xxl dw-radio about dw-radio what 's on ?
reception audio on demand learning by ear dw-tv what 's on ?
program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de current affairs -pipe- 07.01.2005 bringing home the dead großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : embalmers pick up the bodies from makeshift morgues in thailand , a voluntary team of embalmers is making sure germans who died in the floods can be flown home as soon as possible . while foreign minister joschka fischer arrives in bangkok friday , begining a tour of the worst-affected areas to take a look at where and how berlin 's aid is being spent , some 7000 german survivors have already flown back home . the foreign ministry might have confirmed that the number of dead is lower than previously feared , but the official toll of german lives lost in late december has already reached 60 . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : a woman looks at photographs of the deceased at an emergency relief center in phuket , thailand .
almost two weeks after the devastating tsunami disaster in southeast asia , some 751 germans are registered missing with the police , while up to 300 more are believed lost .
many families are realizing they may never know what happened to their loves ones . as time goes by , tropical temperatures take their toll on the many corpses , making identification even harder .
and until they 've been identified by the federal criminal police office -lrb- bka -rrb- , they ca n't be flown home . embalming in disaster zones international embalming experts are now arriving in the region , tasked with preserving the bodies and thereby facilitating the identification process . sven tittelbach-helmrich from thüringen is one of them . a qualified thanatologist , he and some forty colleagues set up a german-wide organization five and a half years ago called " death care embalming , " which works in disaster-hit regions . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : two women weep as they sit amongst the rubble of their earthquake destroyed house in the city of bingol , southeastern turkey on may 2 , 2003 .
previous missions include the earthquake turkey in 2003 -lrb- photo -rrb- and in taiwan in 1999 . scenes of devastation several days after the floods , tittelbach-helmrich and an embalming team were sent by the government to thailand with officers from the bka . scenes of devastation awaited them in phuket .
wearing protective suits and gas masks , their job was to prepare the bodies of german tourists for transportation back to europe . " in most cases it was n't possible to embalm them properly , because that happens via the vascular system , " he told german public broadcaster mdr .
" the condition of many of the corpses simply did n't allow it .
all we could do was disinfect the organs to slow down the process of decay . " grief mingled with relief bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : a buddhist monk looks at bodies of victims tittelbach-helmrich and his nine colleagues spent a week collecting bodies that had been identified from makeshift morgues in temples .
most of them were german , but others were dutch , swedish and belgian .
it was a week the thanatologist said he 'll never forget . " when i looked at the walls of posters of young women , men , small children , babies i could n't help thinking about the bodies lying in the temples , " he told mdr . what kept him going was the families ' gratitude their dead had been spared a mass grave in thailand and could be buried back home . " when you see their relief you feel you 've done something useful , " he said . dw staff -lrb- jp -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de a gruesome task for criminologists in the wake of last week ’ s tsunamis , some 300 experts are working around the clock to identify victims .
with more than 30 years experience , germany has sent its team of forensic scientists to the region . -lrb- jan .
3 , 2005 -rrb- tourism after the flood thailand , sri lanka and the maldives are among the most popular holiday destinations for germans .
but after the devastation wrought on these and other asian resorts by the tsunamis , will germans still go there in droves ?
-lrb- jan .
5 , 2005 -rrb- training to bury the dead starting this year , germans who want to become undertakers can receive a formal education for the job .
while thousands of young people are still looking for apprenticeships , 75 have already signed up for the program .
-lrb- nov .
14 , 2003 -rrb- radio news listen to world headlines from the top of the hour dw-world.de check out our latest interactive web features dw screensaver social bookmarking our rss feeds dw widgets integrated search dw on facebook newsletters netvibes.com the way you want it mobile optimized for pdas newsletters news in your inbox audio / video podcasts © dw 2011 deutsche welle is not responsible for the content of external websites .

almost two weeks after the devastating tsunami disaster in southeast asia , some 751 germans are registered missing with the police , while up to 300 more are believed lost .
many families are realizing they may never know what happened to their loves ones . as time goes by , tropical temperatures take their toll on the many corpses , making identification even harder .
and until they 've been identified by the federal criminal police office -lrb- bka -rrb- , they ca n't be flown home . embalming in disaster zones international embalming experts are now arriving in the region , tasked with preserving the bodies and thereby facilitating the identification process . sven tittelbach-helmrich from thüringen is one of them . a qualified thanatologist , he and some forty colleagues set up a german-wide organization five and a half years ago called " death care embalming , " which works in disaster-hit regions . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : two women weep as they sit amongst the rubble of their earthquake destroyed house in the city of bingol , southeastern turkey on may 2 , 2003 .
previous missions include the earthquake turkey in 2003 -lrb- photo -rrb- and in taiwan in 1999 . scenes of devastation several days after the floods , tittelbach-helmrich and an embalming team were sent by the government to thailand with officers from the bka . scenes of devastation awaited them in phuket .
wearing protective suits and gas masks , their job was to prepare the bodies of german tourists for transportation back to europe . " in most cases it was n't possible to embalm them properly , because that happens via the vascular system , " he told german public broadcaster mdr .
" the condition of many of the corpses simply did n't allow it .
all we could do was disinfect the organs to slow down the process of decay . " grief mingled with relief bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : a buddhist monk looks at bodies of victims tittelbach-helmrich and his nine colleagues spent a week collecting bodies that had been identified from makeshift morgues in temples .
most of them were german , but others were dutch , swedish and belgian .
it was a week the thanatologist said he 'll never forget . " when i looked at the walls of posters of young women , men , small children , babies i could n't help thinking about the bodies lying in the temples , " he told mdr . what kept him going was the families ' gratitude their dead had been spared a mass grave in thailand and could be buried back home . " when you see their relief you feel you 've done something useful , " he said . dw staff -lrb- jp -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de a gruesome task for criminologists in the wake of last week ’ s tsunamis , some 300 experts are working around the clock to identify victims .
with more than 30 years experience , germany has sent its team of forensic scientists to the region . -lrb- jan .
3 , 2005 -rrb- tourism after the flood thailand , sri lanka and the maldives are among the most popular holiday destinations for germans .
but after the devastation wrought on these and other asian resorts by the tsunamis , will germans still go there in droves ?

while thousands of young people are still looking for apprenticeships , 75 have already signed up for the program .

program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de current affairs -pipe- 07.01.2005 bringing home the dead großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : embalmers pick up the bodies from makeshift morgues in thailand , a voluntary team of embalmers is making sure germans who died in the floods can be flown home as soon as possible . while foreign minister joschka fischer arrives in bangkok friday , begining a tour of the worst-affected areas to take a look at where and how berlin 's aid is being spent , some 7000 german survivors have already flown back home . the foreign ministry might have confirmed that the number of dead is lower than previously feared , but the official toll of german lives lost in late december has already reached 60 . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : a woman looks at photographs of the deceased at an emergency relief center in phuket , thailand .
almost two weeks after the devastating tsunami disaster in southeast asia , some 751 germans are registered missing with the police , while up to 300 more are believed lost .
many families are realizing they may never know what happened to their loves ones . as time goes by , tropical temperatures take their toll on the many corpses , making identification even harder .
and until they 've been identified by the federal criminal police office -lrb- bka -rrb- , they ca n't be flown home . embalming in disaster zones international embalming experts are now arriving in the region , tasked with preserving the bodies and thereby facilitating the identification process . sven tittelbach-helmrich from thüringen is one of them . a qualified thanatologist , he and some forty colleagues set up a german-wide organization five and a half years ago called " death care embalming , " which works in disaster-hit regions . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : two women weep as they sit amongst the rubble of their earthquake destroyed house in the city of bingol , southeastern turkey on may 2 , 2003 .
previous missions include the earthquake turkey in 2003 -lrb- photo -rrb- and in taiwan in 1999 . scenes of devastation several days after the floods , tittelbach-helmrich and an embalming team were sent by the government to thailand with officers from the bka . scenes of devastation awaited them in phuket .
wearing protective suits and gas masks , their job was to prepare the bodies of german tourists for transportation back to europe . " in most cases it was n't possible to embalm them properly , because that happens via the vascular system , " he told german public broadcaster mdr .
" the condition of many of the corpses simply did n't allow it .
all we could do was disinfect the organs to slow down the process of decay . " grief mingled with relief bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : a buddhist monk looks at bodies of victims tittelbach-helmrich and his nine colleagues spent a week collecting bodies that had been identified from makeshift morgues in temples .
most of them were german , but others were dutch , swedish and belgian .
it was a week the thanatologist said he 'll never forget . " when i looked at the walls of posters of young women , men , small children , babies i could n't help thinking about the bodies lying in the temples , " he told mdr . what kept him going was the families ' gratitude their dead had been spared a mass grave in thailand and could be buried back home . " when you see their relief you feel you 've done something useful , " he said . dw staff -lrb- jp -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de a gruesome task for criminologists in the wake of last week ’ s tsunamis , some 300 experts are working around the clock to identify victims .
with more than 30 years experience , germany has sent its team of forensic scientists to the region . -lrb- jan .
3 , 2005 -rrb- tourism after the flood thailand , sri lanka and the maldives are among the most popular holiday destinations for germans .
but after the devastation wrought on these and other asian resorts by the tsunamis , will germans still go there in droves ?
-lrb- jan .
5 , 2005 -rrb- training to bury the dead starting this year , germans who want to become undertakers can receive a formal education for the job .
while thousands of young people are still looking for apprenticeships , 75 have already signed up for the program .

program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de current affairs -pipe- 07.01.2005 bringing home the dead großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : embalmers pick up the bodies from makeshift morgues in thailand , a voluntary team of embalmers is making sure germans who died in the floods can be flown home as soon as possible . while foreign minister joschka fischer arrives in bangkok friday , begining a tour of the worst-affected areas to take a look at where and how berlin 's aid is being spent , some 7000 german survivors have already flown back home . the foreign ministry might have confirmed that the number of dead is lower than previously feared , but the official toll of german lives lost in late december has already reached 60 . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : a woman looks at photographs of the deceased at an emergency relief center in phuket , thailand .
almost two weeks after the devastating tsunami disaster in southeast asia , some 751 germans are registered missing with the police , while up to 300 more are believed lost .
many families are realizing they may never know what happened to their loves ones . as time goes by , tropical temperatures take their toll on the many corpses , making identification even harder .
and until they 've been identified by the federal criminal police office -lrb- bka -rrb- , they ca n't be flown home . embalming in disaster zones international embalming experts are now arriving in the region , tasked with preserving the bodies and thereby facilitating the identification process . sven tittelbach-helmrich from thüringen is one of them . a qualified thanatologist , he and some forty colleagues set up a german-wide organization five and a half years ago called " death care embalming , " which works in disaster-hit regions . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : two women weep as they sit amongst the rubble of their earthquake destroyed house in the city of bingol , southeastern turkey on may 2 , 2003 .
previous missions include the earthquake turkey in 2003 -lrb- photo -rrb- and in taiwan in 1999 . scenes of devastation several days after the floods , tittelbach-helmrich and an embalming team were sent by the government to thailand with officers from the bka . scenes of devastation awaited them in phuket .
wearing protective suits and gas masks , their job was to prepare the bodies of german tourists for transportation back to europe . " in most cases it was n't possible to embalm them properly , because that happens via the vascular system , " he told german public broadcaster mdr .
" the condition of many of the corpses simply did n't allow it .
all we could do was disinfect the organs to slow down the process of decay . " grief mingled with relief bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : a buddhist monk looks at bodies of victims tittelbach-helmrich and his nine colleagues spent a week collecting bodies that had been identified from makeshift morgues in temples .
most of them were german , but others were dutch , swedish and belgian .
it was a week the thanatologist said he 'll never forget . " when i looked at the walls of posters of young women , men , small children , babies i could n't help thinking about the bodies lying in the temples , " he told mdr . what kept him going was the families ' gratitude their dead had been spared a mass grave in thailand and could be buried back home . " when you see their relief you feel you 've done something useful , " he said . dw staff -lrb- jp -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de a gruesome task for criminologists in the wake of last week ’ s tsunamis , some 300 experts are working around the clock to identify victims .
with more than 30 years experience , germany has sent its team of forensic scientists to the region . -lrb- jan .

while thousands of young people are still looking for apprenticeships , 75 have already signed up for the program .

bringing home the dead -pipe- current affairs -pipe- deutsche welle -pipe- 07.01.2005 main content main navigation extra content head navigation search choose form 30 languages about us press business & sales dw-akademie contact help partner site map archive search keywords search extended search your link to germany choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages english german chinese spanish portuguese for brazil arabic russian persian albanian amharic bengali bosnian b / h / s bulgarian croatian dari french greek hausa hindi indonesian kiswahili macedonian pashto polish portuguese for africa romanian serbian turkish ukrainian urdu choose from 30 languages 28.05.2011 home news germany europe world asia business science & technology environment & development culture & lifestyle sports germany info visit germany facts about germany study in germany german courses learning german deutsch unterrichten german xxl dw-radio about dw-radio what 's on ?
reception audio on demand learning by ear dw-tv what 's on ?
program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de current affairs -pipe- 07.01.2005 bringing home the dead großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : embalmers pick up the bodies from makeshift morgues in thailand , a voluntary team of embalmers is making sure germans who died in the floods can be flown home as soon as possible . while foreign minister joschka fischer arrives in bangkok friday , begining a tour of the worst-affected areas to take a look at where and how berlin 's aid is being spent , some 7000 german survivors have already flown back home . the foreign ministry might have confirmed that the number of dead is lower than previously feared , but the official toll of german lives lost in late december has already reached 60 . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : a woman looks at photographs of the deceased at an emergency relief center in phuket , thailand .
almost two weeks after the devastating tsunami disaster in southeast asia , some 751 germans are registered missing with the police , while up to 300 more are believed lost .
many families are realizing they may never know what happened to their loves ones . as time goes by , tropical temperatures take their toll on the many corpses , making identification even harder .
and until they 've been identified by the federal criminal police office -lrb- bka -rrb- , they ca n't be flown home . embalming in disaster zones international embalming experts are now arriving in the region , tasked with preserving the bodies and thereby facilitating the identification process . sven tittelbach-helmrich from thüringen is one of them . a qualified thanatologist , he and some forty colleagues set up a german-wide organization five and a half years ago called " death care embalming , " which works in disaster-hit regions . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : two women weep as they sit amongst the rubble of their earthquake destroyed house in the city of bingol , southeastern turkey on may 2 , 2003 .
previous missions include the earthquake turkey in 2003 -lrb- photo -rrb- and in taiwan in 1999 . scenes of devastation several days after the floods , tittelbach-helmrich and an embalming team were sent by the government to thailand with officers from the bka . scenes of devastation awaited them in phuket .
wearing protective suits and gas masks , their job was to prepare the bodies of german tourists for transportation back to europe . " in most cases it was n't possible to embalm them properly , because that happens via the vascular system , " he told german public broadcaster mdr .
" the condition of many of the corpses simply did n't allow it .
all we could do was disinfect the organs to slow down the process of decay . " grief mingled with relief bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : a buddhist monk looks at bodies of victims tittelbach-helmrich and his nine colleagues spent a week collecting bodies that had been identified from makeshift morgues in temples .
most of them were german , but others were dutch , swedish and belgian .
it was a week the thanatologist said he 'll never forget . " when i looked at the walls of posters of young women , men , small children , babies i could n't help thinking about the bodies lying in the temples , " he told mdr . what kept him going was the families ' gratitude their dead had been spared a mass grave in thailand and could be buried back home . " when you see their relief you feel you 've done something useful , " he said . dw staff -lrb- jp -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de a gruesome task for criminologists in the wake of last week ’ s tsunamis , some 300 experts are working around the clock to identify victims .
with more than 30 years experience , germany has sent its team of forensic scientists to the region . -lrb- jan .
3 , 2005 -rrb- tourism after the flood thailand , sri lanka and the maldives are among the most popular holiday destinations for germans .
but after the devastation wrought on these and other asian resorts by the tsunamis , will germans still go there in droves ?
-lrb- jan .
5 , 2005 -rrb- training to bury the dead starting this year , germans who want to become undertakers can receive a formal education for the job .
while thousands of young people are still looking for apprenticeships , 75 have already signed up for the program .
-lrb- nov .
14 , 2003 -rrb- radio news listen to world headlines from the top of the hour dw-world.de check out our latest interactive web features dw screensaver social bookmarking our rss feeds dw widgets integrated search dw on facebook newsletters netvibes.com the way you want it mobile optimized for pdas newsletters news in your inbox audio / video podcasts © dw 2011 deutsche welle is not responsible for the content of external websites .

bringing home the dead -pipe- current affairs -pipe- deutsche welle -pipe- 07.01.2005 main content main navigation extra content head navigation search choose form 30 languages about us press business & sales dw-akademie dw-store contact help partner site map archive search keywords search extended search your link to germany choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages english german chinese spanish portuguese for brazil arabic russian persian albanian amharic bengali bosnian b / h / s bulgarian croatian dari french greek hausa hindi indonesian kiswahili macedonian pashto polish portuguese for africa romanian serbian turkish ukrainian urdu choose from 30 languages 22.04.2011 home news germany europe world asia business science & technology environment & development culture & lifestyle sports germany info visit germany facts about germany study in germany german courses learning german deutsch unterrichten german xxl dw-radio about dw-radio what 's on ?

program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de current affairs -pipe- 07.01.2005 bringing home the dead großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : embalmers pick up the bodies from makeshift morgues in thailand , a voluntary team of embalmers is making sure germans who died in the floods can be flown home as soon as possible . while foreign minister joschka fischer arrives in bangkok friday , begining a tour of the worst-affected areas to take a look at where and how berlin 's aid is being spent , some 7000 german survivors have already flown back home . the foreign ministry might have confirmed that the number of dead is lower than previously feared , but the official toll of german lives lost in late december has already reached 60 . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : a woman looks at photographs of the deceased at an emergency relief center in phuket , thailand .
almost two weeks after the devastating tsunami disaster in southeast asia , some 751 germans are registered missing with the police , while up to 300 more are believed lost .
many families are realizing they may never know what happened to their loves ones . as time goes by , tropical temperatures take their toll on the many corpses , making identification even harder .
and until they 've been identified by the federal criminal police office -lrb- bka -rrb- , they ca n't be flown home . embalming in disaster zones international embalming experts are now arriving in the region , tasked with preserving the bodies and thereby facilitating the identification process . sven tittelbach-helmrich from thüringen is one of them . a qualified thanatologist , he and some forty colleagues set up a german-wide organization five and a half years ago called " death care embalming , " which works in disaster-hit regions . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : two women weep as they sit amongst the rubble of their earthquake destroyed house in the city of bingol , southeastern turkey on may 2 , 2003 .
previous missions include the earthquake turkey in 2003 -lrb- photo -rrb- and in taiwan in 1999 . scenes of devastation several days after the floods , tittelbach-helmrich and an embalming team were sent by the government to thailand with officers from the bka . scenes of devastation awaited them in phuket .
wearing protective suits and gas masks , their job was to prepare the bodies of german tourists for transportation back to europe . " in most cases it was n't possible to embalm them properly , because that happens via the vascular system , " he told german public broadcaster mdr .
" the condition of many of the corpses simply did n't allow it .
all we could do was disinfect the organs to slow down the process of decay . " grief mingled with relief bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : a buddhist monk looks at bodies of victims tittelbach-helmrich and his nine colleagues spent a week collecting bodies that had been identified from makeshift morgues in temples .
most of them were german , but others were dutch , swedish and belgian .
it was a week the thanatologist said he 'll never forget . " when i looked at the walls of posters of young women , men , small children , babies i could n't help thinking about the bodies lying in the temples , " he told mdr . what kept him going was the families ' gratitude their dead had been spared a mass grave in thailand and could be buried back home . " when you see their relief you feel you 've done something useful , " he said . dw staff -lrb- jp -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de a gruesome task for criminologists in the wake of last week ’ s tsunamis , some 300 experts are working around the clock to identify victims .
with more than 30 years experience , germany has sent its team of forensic scientists to the region . -lrb- jan .
3 , 2005 -rrb- tourism after the flood thailand , sri lanka and the maldives are among the most popular holiday destinations for germans .
but after the devastation wrought on these and other asian resorts by the tsunamis , will germans still go there in droves ?
-lrb- jan .
5 , 2005 -rrb- training to bury the dead starting this year , germans who want to become undertakers can receive a formal education for the job .
while thousands of young people are still looking for apprenticeships , 75 have already signed up for the program .
-lrb- nov .
14 , 2003 -rrb- feedback if you would like to comment on this story , please include your name and country of residence . radio news listen to world headlines from the top of the hour dw-world.de check out our latest interactive web features dw screensaver social bookmarking our rss feeds dw widgets integrated search dw on facebook newsletters netvibes.com the way you want it mobile optimized for pdas newsletters news in your inbox audio / video podcasts © dw 2011 deutsche welle is not responsible for the content of external websites .

program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de current affairs -pipe- 07.01.2005 bringing home the dead großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : embalmers pick up the bodies from makeshift morgues in thailand , a voluntary team of embalmers is making sure germans who died in the floods can be flown home as soon as possible . while foreign minister joschka fischer arrives in bangkok friday , begining a tour of the worst-affected areas to take a look at where and how berlin 's aid is being spent , some 7000 german survivors have already flown back home . the foreign ministry might have confirmed that the number of dead is lower than previously feared , but the official toll of german lives lost in late december has already reached 60 . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : a woman looks at photographs of the deceased at an emergency relief center in phuket , thailand .
almost two weeks after the devastating tsunami disaster in southeast asia , some 751 germans are registered missing with the police , while up to 300 more are believed lost .
many families are realizing they may never know what happened to their loves ones . as time goes by , tropical temperatures take their toll on the many corpses , making identification even harder .
and until they 've been identified by the federal criminal police office -lrb- bka -rrb- , they ca n't be flown home . embalming in disaster zones international embalming experts are now arriving in the region , tasked with preserving the bodies and thereby facilitating the identification process . sven tittelbach-helmrich from thüringen is one of them . a qualified thanatologist , he and some forty colleagues set up a german-wide organization five and a half years ago called " death care embalming , " which works in disaster-hit regions . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : two women weep as they sit amongst the rubble of their earthquake destroyed house in the city of bingol , southeastern turkey on may 2 , 2003 .
previous missions include the earthquake turkey in 2003 -lrb- photo -rrb- and in taiwan in 1999 . scenes of devastation several days after the floods , tittelbach-helmrich and an embalming team were sent by the government to thailand with officers from the bka . scenes of devastation awaited them in phuket .
wearing protective suits and gas masks , their job was to prepare the bodies of german tourists for transportation back to europe . " in most cases it was n't possible to embalm them properly , because that happens via the vascular system , " he told german public broadcaster mdr .
" the condition of many of the corpses simply did n't allow it .
all we could do was disinfect the organs to slow down the process of decay . " grief mingled with relief bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : a buddhist monk looks at bodies of victims tittelbach-helmrich and his nine colleagues spent a week collecting bodies that had been identified from makeshift morgues in temples .
most of them were german , but others were dutch , swedish and belgian .
it was a week the thanatologist said he 'll never forget . " when i looked at the walls of posters of young women , men , small children , babies i could n't help thinking about the bodies lying in the temples , " he told mdr . what kept him going was the families ' gratitude their dead had been spared a mass grave in thailand and could be buried back home . " when you see their relief you feel you 've done something useful , " he said . dw staff -lrb- jp -rrb- send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic dw-world.de a gruesome task for criminologists in the wake of last week ’ s tsunamis , some 300 experts are working around the clock to identify victims .
with more than 30 years experience , germany has sent its team of forensic scientists to the region . -lrb- jan .
3 , 2005 -rrb- tourism after the flood thailand , sri lanka and the maldives are among the most popular holiday destinations for germans .
but after the devastation wrought on these and other asian resorts by the tsunamis , will germans still go there in droves ?
-lrb- jan .
5 , 2005 -rrb- training to bury the dead starting this year , germans who want to become undertakers can receive a formal education for the job .
while thousands of young people are still looking for apprenticeships , 75 have already signed up for the program .
-lrb- nov .
14 , 2003 -rrb- feedback if you would like to comment on this story , please include your name and country of residence . radio news listen to world headlines from the top of the hour dw-world.de check out our latest interactive web features dw screensaver social bookmarking our rss feeds dw widgets integrated search dw on facebook newsletters netvibes.com the way you want it mobile optimized for pdas newsletters news in your inbox audio / video podcasts © dw 2011 deutsche welle is not responsible for the content of external websites .
